Pharmaceutical Science, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, 310014, PR China College of Pharmaceutical Science Zhejiang University of Technology Hangzhou 310014 PR China This study presents the development of ruthenium complexes with chiral phosphine ligands for the efficient asymmetric hydrogenation of β-keto esters in a continuous-flow reactor. By employing Bayesian optimization for multi-parameter screening, we identified the optimal Segphos-Ru catalyst and reaction conditions in just 48 experiments, enabling the preparation of the desired chiral alcohols in under 20 minutes. In addition, three catalysts from the Segphos-Ru catalyst were synthesized using various preparation methods, revealing distinct trends in activity and enantioselectivity with varying water content. Notably, the Ru@Seg III catalyst achieved the highest enantioselectivity (95%) at a water/substrate equivalency (v/v) of 0.2. Finally, the possible pathways of asymmetric hydrogenation catalyzed by the ionic hydrogenation catalyst in low-water organic media were elucidated using experimental data and density functional theory computations. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ruthenium complexes chiral phosphine asymmetric hydrogenation Bayesian optimization enantioselectivity Data availability I have shared the supporting information at the Attach File step Introduction Chiral alcohols are essential structural motifs in biologically active pharmaceuticals, agricultural chemicals, fragrances, and other fine chemicals [1,2]. The increasing focus on safe usage, specificity, and atom economy has driven the development of efficient methods for the stereoselective synthesis of chiral alcohols. While advancements in the asymmetric hydrogenation (AH) of chiral alcohols are promising, there remains a need for more sustainable preparation methods and the exploration of additional functional products [3]. In addition, many current protocols rely on strong bases or light irradiation, limiting their practicality and suitability for high-complexity substrates and biomolecules [4]. Furthermore, the significant air sensitivity of organometallic catalysts restricts their synthetic applicability, as they require specialized storage and handling techniques that impede their broader adoption in typical synthetic laboratories and industrial environments [5]. Inspired by Noyori's pioneering work on BINAP chemistry, numerous atropisomeric biaryl bisphosphine ligands have been developed [6–9]. Despite these advancements, the influence of water on the activity and enantioselectivity of organometallic catalysts incorporating these ligands remains poorly understood [10–12]. Notably, the introduction of small quantities of water has been observed to enhance the reaction rate of AH catalyzed by BINAP-Ru(II) complexes, albeit with a reduction in enantioselectivity [13,14]. Similarly, Schrock demonstrated that monophosphine-Rh catalysts in 1% aqueous solution could accelerate the AH of ketones, although further water addition led to a slight decrease in reaction rate [15]. To elucidate these observations, a deep investigation into the catalytic mechanism of this reaction in the low-water organic media is warranted [16–19]. Bayesian optimization is a machine learning approach that has recently gained attention as a promising solution to the limitations of conventional optimization techniques [20–28]. Not only can Bayesian optimization efficiently explore vast chemical reaction spaces, but it also enables the simultaneous optimization of categorical and numerical variables, predicting high-yield conditions with far fewer experiments [21,29,30]. Therefore, known for its ability to optimize computationally expensive objective functions, this uncertainty-guided response surface method has seen numerous applications [31–36]. In flow chemistry, Bayesian optimization has been applied successfully in organocatalysis, including reactions like the Suzuki-Miyaura [21,37,38], the Buchwald-Hartwig C-N cross-coupling [30], and the Ullmann-Goldberg C-N cross-coupling [29]. Despite its widespread use in optimizing chemical processes and catalyst investigation [39–43], the application of Bayesian optimization in developing AH reactions is limited. Additionally, there is an urgent need to understand the role of water on metal catalysts for preparing chiral alcohols, especially with restricted experimental resources. Such insights would pave the way for more sustainable and environmentally friendly production methods, reducing waste generation. In this study, we used Ethyl 4-chloroacetoacetate (COBE) as a model substrate to prepare (R)-Ethyl-4-Chloro-3-Hydroxybutyrate (CHBE) and developed a workflow to efficiently identify the experimental conditions that maximize conversion and enantioselectivity (Fig. 1 ). Bayesian optimization was implemented using the latest version of the FlowBO platform developed by our group [44], which employs Gaussian Processes (GP) as the surrogate function and qNEHVI as the acquisition function. Previous studies have indicated that the activity and selectivity of Ru(bisphosphine)-type catalysts are influenced by their preparation methods [13]. Therefore, after determining the optimal reaction conditions and ionic catalysts, we further explored the how different preparation methods, including various reactors and solvents, impact the catalytic activity. In addition, by combining experimental work with density functional theory (DFT) calculations, we examined the effect of water on the reaction rate and enantioselectivity of the ionic hydrogenation catalysts. Results and discussion Optimization of catalysts and reaction conditions Given the complexity of the reaction system, efficiently identifying optimal conditions requires a systematic and data-driven approach. The combination of all the variables in the reaction results in over 7 million possible experiments (Figure S2), making manual optimization impractical. As a result, Bayesian optimization was employed to streamline the process. The first step in Bayesian optimization involves defining the reaction conditions to be optimized and their respective search space. The range of continuous variables and the candidate pool of the bisphosphine ligands are shown in Scheme 1 . Specifically, to set up a broad search space for exploration, the temperature and substrate/catalyst (S/C) ratio ranges in our continuous variables were set to 60-160°C and 200-4000, respectively. Meanwhile, we intentionally narrowed the range of hydrogen pressures (0.5-2 MPa) and reaction times (4-20 min) to enhance the reaction's intrinsic safety and environmental sustainability. Additionally, we identified eight bisphosphine ligands, taking into account their availability and roles in catalyst performance [45–47]. We initialized multi-objective Bayesian optimization with a Latin Hypercube Sampling (LHS) phase consisting of 10 experiments conducted in a continuous flow reactor. This was followed by an iteration phase comprising 19 rounds, with 2 experiments performed per iteration. The LHS sampled variable combinations roughly covered the search space with an unbiased initial exploration [12,21,48], and the results obtained had the conversion between 2.4% and 94% and ee values between 86% and 99% (Fig. 2 ). Afterward, with the help of the qNEHVI as the acquisition function, the iteration phase gradually approaches the optimal targets while maintaining a balance between exploration and exploitation to avoid falling into a local optimum [49–51]. The algorithm converges to an optimal solution at iteration 13 with a conversion of more than 99% and an ee of 99%, as is shown in the upper right corner of Fig. 2. The results from Bayesian optimization highlight that ligands for ruthenium catalyst are crucial in determining the conversion and enantioselectivity of the AH reaction (Fig. 3 ), aligning with previously reported studies [52,53]. Among the ligands tested, the Segphos bisphosphine ligand demonstrated the best overall performance, achieving complete conversion and up to 99% ee. Temperature is an important factor affecting the bisphosphine-Ru catalyst. At temperatures above 120°C, the conversion for the Segphos, Difluorphos, BINAP, and Chiraphos bisphosphine ligands exceeded 90%, with ee values up to 99%. Conversely, at temperatures below 120°C, except for Difluorphos and Segphos, the conversion for the substrate fell below 50%, and ee values decreased even if the reaction time or the amount of catalyst increased. However, higher temperatures are not always advantageous, as the target compounds were completely undetected when Ru-Difluorphos was used as the catalyst at reaction temperatures approaching 160°C (see SI, Table S1). Contrary to literature reports [13,14,54], efficient conversion with excellent enantioselectivity was achieved under both low and high hydrogen pressure, implying that hydrogen pressure has little effect on the catalytic activity of the Ru complex catalyst in a continuous flow reactor. Exploring the diverse catalytic activity of ionic catalyst While Bayesian optimization identifies optimal catalytic activity, the ruthenium catalyst exhibits high sensitivity to water, which can significantly reduce its catalytic performance or stereoselectivity in the presence of trace amounts of water in the reaction medium [18]. Furthermore, although the ruthenium catalyst generates the same intermediates in the catalytic cycle, subtle variations in preparation conditions can lead to notable differences in reactivity and stereoselectivity [13,55]. Currently, these catalysts are predominantly prepared in batch reactors, with only limited studies reporting their preparation in flow chemistry reactors. To address this, we prepared SegPhos-Ru catalysts in both batch and flow chemistry reactors using reported preparation conditions and evaluated their catalytic activities in organic solvents containing varying amounts of water. Three types of SegPhos-Ru catalysts—Ru@Seg I, Ru@Seg II, and Ru@Seg III—were synthesized using different methods (see Figure S6-7 in the SI). Ru@Seg I was prepared in a batch reactor, while Ru@Seg II and Ru@Seg III were prepared in a continuous flow reactor, with Ru@Seg III receiving preheating treatment. Despite the varied preparation methods, all catalysts shared the same chemical compositions, with the NMR and HRMS data consistent with previously reported literature [56]. Next, we further investigated the reaction rates and enantioselectivities of the AH reactions catalyzed by Ru@Seg I, Ru@Seg II, and Ru@Seg III in a continuous flow reactor with varying water/substrate equivalency ranging from 0 to 1 (Figs. 4 a,4b and see the SI Table S2). All Segphos-Ru complexes achieved complete substrate conversion of substrates in pure ethanol (no water), with Ru@Seg II showing the highest enantioselectivity, reaching up to 92% ee. Conversely, at the highest water content (water/substrate equivalency = 1), Ru@Seg II and Ru@Seg III exhibited the highest catalytic activity. Generally, the reaction rates for all three catalysts showed a tendency to decrease and then increase with rising water content. This trend aligns with observations by Osborn et al. on Rh catalysts [15]. Figs. 4a and 4b illustrate that as the water equivalency increases from 0, the reaction rate of Ru@Seg II decreases most rapidly, followed by Ru@Seg III and then Ru@Seg I, before gradually increasing again. Conversely, the enantioselectivity of Ru@Seg II and Ru@Seg III initially increased and then decreased, whereas the enantioselectivity of Ru@Seg I consistently dropped. This trend of Ru@Seg I aligns with the findings by Noroyi et al. on Ru(BINAP)-catalyzed reduction [13] and with commercial SegPhos-Ru catalysts (CatNo. DGA940, Bidepharm and CatNo. Le091398910, Leyan, Shanghai, China). Specifically, at a water equivalent of 0.03, Ru@Seg II showed a significantly inhibited conversion (25%) but the highest enantioselectivity, whereas Ru@Seg I and Ru@Seg III maintained catalytic activities comparable to anhydrous conditions. Similarly, at a water equivalency of about 0.2, the reaction rate of Ru@Seg III was severely inhibited (yield dropped to 30%), but it achieved the highest enantioselectivity at 95% ee. Thus, the water equivalencies 0.03 and 0.2 enhanced the enantioselectivity of Ru@Seg II and Ru@Seg III, respectively, albeit with reduced reaction rates. To further investigate the influence of water on the catalysts, we monitored the temperature changes in the reaction systems under different conditions (Fig. 4c). In anhydrous ethanol, all three catalysts exhibited steady temperature increases, indicating consistent catalytic activity. However, upon adding water, distinct differences emerged: the Ru@Seg III system (red) showed a moderate temperature rise, while the Ru@Seg II system (blue) exhibited a more pronounced increase. In contrast, the Ru@Seg I system (green) remained unaffected by the addition of water, displaying behavior similar to the control reaction conducted in anhydrous ethanol (pink). These temperature variation patterns align with the observed trends in catalytic activity decline (Fig. 4a), where Ru@Seg II experienced the fastest deactivation, while Ru@Seg I remained stable. Previous studies [16,57,58] suggest that the presence of water in these reactions often leads to the formation of catalytically inactive aqua or hydroxo complexes (Cp*Ru-H2O). Additionally, differences in catalyst preparation methods may influence the rate at which these inactive complexes form in the presence of water. The mechanism underlying this dissociation will be discussed in detail in the next section. Mechanism explanation In this section, we explore the catalytic mechanism of the optimal ionic catalyst Ru@Seg III in ethanol with varying water contents. We discuss the catalytic mechanism in anhydrous ethanol, the inhibitory effect of small amounts of water on the reaction rate, and the acceleration of the reaction rate with increased water content. We proposed a potential hydrogenation pathway via an outer sphere mechanism for the hydrogenation of ketone esters in an anhydrous ethanol environment (Scheme 2 ) [6,59–61]. Initially, treating catalyst A with H2 in EtOH generates a molecule of hydrochloric acid, and the active cationic hydrido catalyst B is derived from the cationic chloride complex A [61,62]. The cationic catalyst B then reacts with the keto ester to form complex C. Subsequently, the carbonyl substrate extracts the hydride from Ru(II)H and releases it from compound D by getting the proton from hydrochloric acid, thereby completing the hydrogenation transfer. Finally, the cationic Ru(II) complex E interacts with hydrogen to regenerate catalyst B. HRMS of the reaction solution showed exact mass of 847.1700 and 881.1301, respectively, confirming the presence of catalyst B and catalyst E (see the SI Figure S14). To gain a deeper insight into the reaction mechanism involving water, we performed deuterium labeling experiments using D2O and investigated the impact of H+ concentration on the reaction rate. The experiments (Scheme 3 A, eq. (1)-(3)) demonstrated that the concentration of H+ in the reaction system is critical to the reaction rate [59]. An increase in H+ concentration enabled complete substrate conversion, even with just 0.25 equivalents of water, achieving up to 96% ee. Besides, while the reaction rate initially decreased and then increased with increasing water content, only trace amounts of the target product were detected when ethanol was replaced with water as the solvent, which could be due to the reactants’ insolubility in water. Subsequently, substituting water with D2O in the reaction system led to the observation of the corresponding deuterated product (see the SI Figure S16-19). When the reaction was performed with 0.25 equivalents of D2O, approximately 5% deuterium incorporation at the α-H position of the hydroxyl group (Scheme 3A, eq. (4)). Increasing the D2O amount to 1 equivalent raised the deuterium incorporation from 5 to 25 % (Scheme 3A, eq. (5)-(6)). Conversely, using deuterated ethanol in place of anhydrous ethanol resulted in less than 5% deuterated product detection. Based on these deuteration experiments, we propose that a hydrogen-deuterium exchange between the hydride Ru complex and D2O forms a deuterated Ru(II) complex (Scheme 3B) [63]. Hence, we propose a catalyst mechanism under varying water contents. For small amounts of water that inhibit the reaction rate, we suggest a mechanism different from that in an anhydrous ethanol solvent (Scheme 4 A). According to Scheme 3A's experiments, a change in hydrogen ion concentration may cause the reaction rate to decrease in systems with small amounts of water. When water undergoes H-H exchange with the hydrogen on compound B, the generated base reduces the hydrogen ion concentration in the reaction system. Meanwhile, although protons are generated during the formation of compound B-2 to compensate for the hydrogen ion depletion of the base, the gradual nature of the reaction still changes the hydrogen ion concentration in the system to some extent(SI, Figure S20). This change may affect the hydrogenated substrate's ability to extract protons from hydrochloric acid, thus slowing the release from compound D-1. Additionally, the formation of the inactive Cp*Ru-H2O from catalyst and water may also be responsible for the decrease in catalytic activity [16,58,64]. Conversely, according to deuterium labeling experiments, the hydrogen ion concentration in the system varies more significantly during water-accelerated catalysis. We proposed that water may form hydrogen-bonding interactions with the substrate rather than participating in the catalytic cycle through carbonyl compound activation by hydrogen ions (Scheme 4B) [16,18,65]. Upon transfer of hydrogen from Ru(II)H to the carbonyl carbon of the substrate, the substrate is released from compound D-2 by solvent molecules and acquires hydrogen ions in the system, resulting in the formation of the corresponding chiral alcohol. Based on our experimental investigations and mechanistic hypothesis, we performed preliminary density-functional theory (DFT) calculations to provide a rational explanation for the observed changes in enantioselectivity and reaction rate acceleration (Fig. 5 ). Initially, we used the number of water molecules to model the increasing water content in the ethanol solvent. As anticipated, when the reaction rate of Ru@Seg III was inhibited by water, the water molecule did not initially form a hydrogen-bond with the substrate (Fig. 5A, C-1, 3.16 Å). However, with the increase in water content (Fig. 5B), the rate of hydrogen bond formation between water molecules and the carbonyl group at C-2 was significantly faster than that at C-1, which may help accelerate the catalyst's reaction rate [16,17]. According to DFT calculations, there is a transition state TS (1/2) between the intermediate states C (1/2) and D (1/2). Interestingly, the presence of water influenced the dihedral angle of the transition state. Specifically, the dihedral angle of TS-1 (70.62°) was the largest, followed by TS-2 (68.46°), while the transition state under anhydrous ethanol conditions had the smallest dihedral angle (67.34°, see the SI Table S3). In conjunction with the enantioselectivity of the ionic catalyst Ru@Seg III in ethanol with different water contents, we speculate that changes in the dihedral angle may alter the enantioselectivity of the catalyst. The increase in dihedral angle in the state TS-1 supports the enantioselectivity of Ru@Seg III during the transfer of hydrogen from Ru(II)H to the carbonyl carbon [61,66]. However, the addition of water leads to a displacement of the ketocarbonyl conformation in the C-2 structure away from the metal Ru center (4.65 Å). It may be responsible for the reduced dihedral angle of TS-2, which reduces enantioselectivity. In conclusion, using density-functional theory (DFT), we have speculated on the reasons for the variation in the enantioselectivity of the Ru@Seg III catalyst with the water content in ethanol. Substrate exploration Finally, we chose the reaction conditions recommended by the 13th iteration of BO to study the substrate range for the AH reaction catalyzed by Ru@Seg III (Scheme 5 ). Ru@Seg III achieved high substrate conversion and produced chiral alcohols with high enantioselectivity. Products 3a, 3b, 3c, 3e, and 3g suggested that Ru@Seg III catalysis maintained catalytic activity comparable to the BINAP ligand [67–69], even with lower catalyst loadings and shorter reaction times. For products 3d and 3f, the catalytic activity of Ru@Seg III in water-containing solvents surpassed that in anhydrous solvents. Notably, while the Difluorphos-Ru complex has been reported to exhibit higher catalytic activity [70], the results for product 3d showed that Ru@Seg III in aqueous solution matched the catalytic activity of the Difluorphos-Ru complex and outperformed the BINAP-Ru complex catalysts. Conclusion The study initially screened bisphosphine-Ru catalysts by Bayesian optimization for high catalytic activity and water stability for the AH of β-carbonyl esters. We identified the optimal Segphos-ruthenium complexes and reaction conditions in just 48 experiments, allowing for the preparation of chiral alcohols in under 20 min. Additionally, various preparation methods for the Segphos-ruthenium catalyst were explored, resulting in the production of Ru@Seg I, Ru@Seg II, and Ru@Seg III. Although these complexes generated similar intermediates during the catalytic cycle, slight variations in preparation conditions led to significant differences in reactivity and stereoselectivity. Experimentally results combined with DFT calculations revealed the different catalytic pathways for the Segphos-ruthenium catalyst in different water-containing systems, highlighting the role of water as a hydrogen bond in the AH of carbonyl substrates catalyzed by bisphosphine-Ru catalysts. The broad applicability and operational simplicity of Ru@Seg III in low-water organic media pave the way for discovering and developing more efficient and environmentally friendly catalysts for AH reactions. coredata.dc:description: This study presents the development of ruthenium complexes with chiral phosphine ligands for the efficient asymmetric hydrogenation of β-keto esters in a continuous-flow reactor. By employing Bayesian optimization for multi-parameter screening, we identified the optimal Segphos-Ru catalyst and reaction conditions in just 48 experiments, enabling the preparation of the desired chiral alcohols in under 20 minutes. In addition, three catalysts from the Segphos-Ru catalyst were synthesized using various preparation methods, revealing distinct trends in activity and enantioselectivity with varying water content. Notably, the Ru@Seg III catalyst achieved the highest enantioselectivity (95%) at a water/substrate equivalency (v/v) of 0.2. Finally, the possible pathways of asymmetric hydrogenation catalyzed by the ionic hydrogenation catalyst in low-water organic media were elucidated using experimental data and density functional theory computations.

coredata.dc:title: Optimizing Phosphine Ligands for Ruthenium Catalysts in Asymmetric Hydrogenation of β-Keto Esters: The Role of Water in Activity and Selectivity
